nodes.bodyText: Nit: No need to wrap here

We could keep this as toImmutableList(). Moving away from streams simply to pre-size the output list, in code that's already doing expensive RPC calls, is a hard sell from a code readability standpoint.

This one's a little tricky. It's not exactly the same "memoization" strategy as the rest of the PR, but it's attempting to reduce heap pressure when dealing with a large number of partitions just the same. Since buildPartitionNames is called from getPartitionNamesByFilter which might be requesting all partitions for table, the intermediate copies are material when the partition count is high.
Assuming a JVM without compressed OOPs enabled:

8 bytes per element in the list
initial capacity of 4 (for ImmutableList.builder(), 10 for ArrayList although Collectors.toList() won't trim the resulting list to size which can be a source of wasted heap)

At 1M partitions, that's 7.6MiB for the resulting list and:

18 doubling copies meaning ~16MiB of allocations and copies as the builder grows
One final 7.6MiB copy since the result is not an exact power of 2

So ~7.6MiB instead of ~23.6MiB of allocation and copying by presizing the builder, a material improvement for only a minor stylistic difference.

That's a compelling argument -- let's keep it. One alternative idea would be to use
.collect(toCollection(() -> new ArrayList(partitions.size()))
Import GluePartitionConverter so that it doesn't need to be qualified
You could use a stream here

You could, but for simple transformations like this that are relatively common and when the output list size is guaranteed to be known, I've found defaulting to a sized list to be preferable. See my reply about the buildPartitionNames case.
Obviously, 1M columns is much less likely than 1M partitions, but convertColumns is also performed within each partition conversion so the effect can be much more significant when the number of columns is non-trivial.
So maybe we should improve io.prestosql.util.MoreLists#mappedCopy and make it more commonly used?

@findepi that's a good suggestion. We could do that here and have even more concise code than streams
return mappedCopy(glueColumns, this::convertColumn);

To be clear --  while i am concerned about conciseness, i am even more concerned about "durability" of the change.
builder-based code can easily be later replaced with stream-based in a wholesale fashion. "Improve readability", "Use JDK APIs for mapping lists", etc can be compelling reason to merge such a change. Given we cannot test improvement proposed here, we need to find a non-test way to make it stay with us for longer.
Thus, using mappedCopy alone is not enough. We need to also adorn that method with some explanation why&where it is better than stream/map/list.
Added a comment in to the mappedCopy method explaining the presized builder.

Nit: format empty methods like
private Memoizers() {}

nodes.bodyText:
I think it would be cleaner to make these methods that return standard functional types
public static Function<T, T> memoizeLast() ...

public static Function<I, O> memoizeLast(Function<I, O> transform) ...
Rather than exposing the implementation classes in the usages

nodes.bodyText: Make this private and put it at the end of the class (we put private methods at the end)
i'd rather see the existing io.prestosql.util.MoreLists#mappedCopy being improved & made reusable for hive connector.

Currently doesn't seem like there are any good options. The presto-spi module intentionally avoids depending on Guava and isn't for utilities anyway, so there doesn't seem to be a good location to share the implementation from.

We have some shared classes in presto-plugin-toolkit/src/main/java/io/prestosql/plugin/base/util
(as the name suggests, this is not an ideal location, so once we have more of them, we can find a better home for them)

Having a few duplicated methods between connectors is preferable to presto-plugin-toolkit becoming a "junk drawer". There's a reason we don't have a generic util or common module in Presto. This is fine for now.
I'd check this above, with the other check, since this line is already long
Nit: no need to wrap here
Static import memoizeLast
